NewWords.WordPhrase: n. 烤  a. 烘烤过的  vt. cook with dry heat 烘，烤
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. We had an enormous roast for Sunday lunch.

NewWords.WordPhrase: in or during a known but unspecified past period 曾经，一度
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. It seems quite possible that at one time the two continents were joined together.

NewWords.WordPhrase: survive, manage 生活过得去，过日子
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. You can't get along without water.

NewWords.WordPhrase: vi. grow or expand rapidly 迅速增长（或扩展）
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The population mushroomed in the postwar decades.
e.g. We are missing out on a tremendous opportunity.
e.g. In addition, there are six applicants.

NewWords.WordPhrase: vi. draw in or catch the breath sharply (as with shock) （因惊讶等）倒抽一口气
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The swimmer came out of the water and gasped for breath.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n.,vi.  每天乘车往返两地
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. It's an hour's commute to work.

NewWords.WordPhrase: v. 鞭打  n. 鞭子   whip up make quickly 快速做成
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. I've just about got enough time to whip up an omelet.
e.g. Her blouse doesn't go with her skirt.
e.g. We followed his suggestions, and solved the problems as a result.

NewWords.WordPhrase: become dominant; take control of, especially in place of sth./sb. else 占统治地位；取……而代之
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Even though computers are taking over some of the tasks once accomplished by our own brains, they are not replacing us.

NewWords.WordPhrase: vt. make dizzy or confused 使眩晕（或迷惑） a.（使人） 眩晕的；（使人）迷惑的
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The old woman was dizzied by the strong wind.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. sth. that amuses, especially a performance or show 娱乐演出（或表演），娱乐
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. A cinema is a place of entertainment.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n.  电缆，缆绳；有线电视
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Steel cable will be used to replace worn ropes.
e.g. He didn't talk much, but what he said made sense.

NewWords.WordPhrase: vt. pay money for the use of 租，租借 n. 租金，房租
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The cottage rents for $200 a month.
